sections.content: The 50/30/20 rule is the simplest budgeting framework ever created. Senator Elizabeth Warren popularized it, and millions of families use it because it actually works.

Take your monthly take-home pay (after tax) and split it three ways:

50% → NEEDS — Rent or mortgage, groceries, utilities, transport, insurance. The essentials you can't live without.

30% → WANTS — Dining out, entertainment, subscriptions, shopping, hobbies. The things that make life fun.

20% → SAVINGS & DEBT — Emergency fund, savings goals, extra debt payments. Your future self will thank you.

For example, if you bring home $4,000/month:
• Needs: $2,000
• Wants: $1,200
• Savings: $800

That $800/month in savings becomes $9,600/year. In 5 years, that's $48,000 — enough for a house deposit in many areas!

sections.prompt: What's your monthly take-home pay? Let's see your 50/30/20 split:

sections.content: Don't worry if your split doesn't match perfectly. Many families spend 60% or even 70% on needs — especially with kids. The point is to know your numbers and slowly nudge them in the right direction.
The 50/30/20 rule isn't about perfection — it's a compass, not a cage. Even getting 5% closer to these ratios puts you ahead of most households.
You now have a framework that millionaires use. Seriously. The wealthiest families in the world budget — they just don't talk about it. You're in good company!
